attributes.action: Limit the school week to three days
attributes.background: We want the Government to shorten the school week to three days, from the current five.
attributes.additional_details: Given the current cost of living crisis, and high levels of inflation, we believe it would be better for schools to focus on delivering high-quality education for a three-day week, rather than struggling with the cost of continuing to remain open five days a week. This should reduce energy costs for schools, and travel costs for teachers.

attributes.action: Deliver an emergency budget to deal with the cost of living crisis
attributes.background: The Government is being urged to act by the public, but does not appear to be doing anything to mitigate the impending crisis that millions are facing. An emergency budget must take place as soon as practicable to offer real support to those who are facing wipeout in the autumn and winter.
attributes.additional_details: The Government has the power to introduce a comprehensive support package that can be delivered in time before the utterly scandalous increase in energy prices takes place in the autumn. Whilst this Government's days are numbered, they are paid and elected by us to serve the best interests of the British people, and sitting idly by whilst other countries take appropriate measures is utterly negligent and dangerous.

attributes.action: Ban business premises from leaving lights on after 11pm unnecessarily
attributes.background: Implement a lighting ban after 11pm on businesses that don't operate in the late hours. The ban should be enforced by issuing fines for businesses that don’t comply with the new rules, with all proceeds going directly to combating climate change.
attributes.additional_details: Large scale business premises that leave their lighting on 24:7 undermine the individual attempts to reverse climate change, as the energy they waste is on such a vast scale the efforts of the individual is consequently nullified. It is highly irresponsible and unnecessary for corporations to waste large amounts of energy by leaving lights on for such obscene lengths of time.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Remove the need for consent to install double glazing in listed building
attributes.background: We want the Government to enable owners of listed buildings to install slim-profile double glazing, without needing to seek consent for this, provided the new windows are in the same style as the original windows.
attributes.additional_details:
We believe the Government needs to take action to enable people who own and live in a listed building, at a time when energy bills have increased dramatically, to take steps to reduce their energy costs and carbon emissions.
Now that double glazed windows in many suitable styles are available the Government should enable us look after our heritage in an appropriate and environmentally friendly way, without needing to seek consent.

attributes.action: Reinstate the two year energy price guarantee
attributes.background: Honour the two year energy price ‘guarantee’ that we were promised.
attributes.additional_details: We were promised frozen energy prices for 2 years! Many of us (and not just the ‘most vulnerable’) were facing tough decisions on finances before this came into play. Those tough decisions are now back in the pipeline and it is not just those with the lowest incomes that will struggle - many of us have mortgages that are a commitment we can’t just drop - meaning the ‘eat or heat’ concern is very real.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Reverse restrictions and efforts to reduce imports of Russian coal, oil and gas
attributes.background: British households are facing unprecedented energy and fuel price rises. These rises are happening because there is not enough affordable oil and gas available to the UK. To help solve the Cost of Living Crisis we need to import affordable energy and fuel. Russia's energy sector can help us.
attributes.additional_details:
Energy availability underpins every aspect of our economy.
 
If energy prices are too high for individuals and businesses, not only do we face widespread poverty: we face the imminent collapse of entire sectors. The collapse of society could soon follow.
 
The Government does not appear to be reconsidering its stance on imports of Russian coal, oil and gas. We believe this must change.
 
The war in Ukraine is awful. But is widespread poverty and the destruction of our economy a price worth paying?

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Take action to make essential energy (oil/gas/petrol/electric) more affordable
attributes.background: We want the Government to take action, such as the below, to bring down the cost of essential energy commodities:
attributes.additional_details:
- Price caps

- Tax reductions

- Easily accessible grants for the most vulnerable

- Subsidies for home/small business use

Loans do not solve the root cause of the issue so is a not long term solution

The prices of these commodities are creating a real threat to many households from the financial strain they are imposing. People are fearing cold winters with no heating, debt and bankruptcy as a result.

Leaving behind the most vulnerable in societies and creating more vulnerable households ends up worsening many societal challenges and costing the society and government more in the end.

This also impacts also the health, transport, and education sectors; just to name a few.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Require plastic food containers to contain a minimum percentage recycled plastic
attributes.background: Houses need to have a minimum of insulation. Petrol must contain a minimum of ethanol. We should introduce a minimum requirement that plastic food containers manufactured or sold in the UK (bottles, food packaging, etc) contain a minimum percentage of recycled plastic and to increase this over time.
attributes.additional_details: This will aid in reducing fossil fuel usage and contribute towards green energy commitments. It is consistent with government policy and prior  initiatives to encourage business uptake through legislation

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: End EU Trade Talks if negotiations fail to progress by June and plan exit on WTO
attributes.background: If the PM and his team fails to negotiate a ‘Canada-Style’ free trade deal with the EU by the end of June 2020, that covers fishing, transport, law enforcement and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, transport and energy then the UK should begin immediate preparations to trade on WTO Terms.
attributes.additional_details: There is no reason why negotiations cannot continue between the UK and EU through the use of videoconferencing. The EU is facing recession and is appears to be prolonging talks as long as possible. The post-pandemic period will be dominated by reviving the economy, rebuilding the NHS, driving unemployment down, and regaining a handle on public finances. The UK needs to exit talks as soon as it is clear that a ‘Canada-Style’  FT deal is not on offer.

attributes.action: Launch an inquiry to identify the long-term solutions to current energy crisis
attributes.background: The Government needs to hold an inquiry to address the current energy crisis, and to identify a long-term solution that works in favour or the people.
attributes.additional_details:
It needs to be addressed at the root cause rather than using temporary measures that provide limited respite from the massive increases in price.
 
Many people will be left without food and warmth if the current crisis is not addressed urgently. Most of the nation are worried about how they are going to manage to afford the significant increase on their bills. People should not be worrying about these extortionate prices. We have already seen significant increases during the summer months. The further increases will inevitably have a knock on effect on all products in the supply chain as we've already seen.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Fund a Lunar colony.
attributes.background: Fund and build one or more self-sustainable human outposts on the Earth's moon to act as a staging location for future colonisation of solar system as well as harvesters of Thorium and Helium-3 fuel sources which are abundant on the moon and can be used in Thorium (LFTR) and nuclear fusion reactors.
attributes.additional_details:
With climate change increasing the need for nuclear power as a primary energy source, this government is already investigating modern reactors which use Thorium to increase efficiency, and fusion and LFTR reactors, while still in the early stages of adoption offer greater gains which would justify this course of action in 50 years.

A more human justification is simply that this is the next logical step for our civilisation, and shows that we have faith in our collective futures in the universe.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Supply NHS key frontline staff working during Covid-19 healthy food hampers
attributes.background: Government to supply and issue deliveries of healthy food hampers to hospitals to be distributed to NHS key front line critical staff working during Covid-19
attributes.additional_details: Because these critical staff may be unable to shop during times when there is stock in the supermarket due to shift patterns. When they arrive after they finish work there may be nothing left due to panic buying and stock piling. This can result in hungry and stressed NHS key front line critical staff who may not have the energy to work when needed. We need to support these people and their wellbeing.

departments.name: Department of Health and Social Care

attributes.action: Lower energy prices down again, to levels affordable for all people!!
attributes.background:
I want the government to look at the prices of energy. Gas prices are extortionate. I am a single parent of 3 children and my daily gas usage is £14 a DAY. This is not acceptable. 
My electric is around £5-£7 PER DAY!!!
attributes.additional_details:
I refuse to allow my children to be cold in 2022!!! People are going to die by freezing to death in their own homes, because they cannot afford to heat their homes! 
Mr Prime minister would you allow your children,  mother, grandmother to sit in their house in the cold? No I didn't think so!? 
Capping the energy bills to March 2023 of £2,500 then allowing it to rise to £3000 PER YEAR isn't good enough! 
People/vulnerable people will die this winter. 
Energy prices need to go back down and fast!!

attributes.action: Stop the coalmine in Cumbria.
attributes.background:
Michael Gove has approved plans for the UK will build its first new coalmine for three decades in Cumbria, despite objections locally, across the UK and from around the world.
It will cause an estimated 400,000 tonnes of greenhouse gas emissions a year.
attributes.additional_details:
This puts the fossil fuel industry before people and the planet and cancels out any progress Britain has made on renewable energy.

This is investing in the damaging sources of energy from the last century and not the clean energy needed for children's future.

A new coalmine would have no impact on reducing energy bills or ensuring our energy security.

There is an urgent need to reduce the consumption of fossil fuels and this is  undermining the most important global issue of our times

attributes.action: Establish an independent energy policy including onshore gas extraction.
attributes.background: To maintain a viable economy and lessen the threats from Russia and unreliable autocracies the United Kingdom should establish a safe, environmentally friendly, commercial viable and independent onshore gas extraction industry. Such an industry won’t delay Net Zero but help defend us strategically.
attributes.additional_details:
Europe including the UK face an existential threat from the Russian invasion of Ukraine. Mr Putin is threatening to cut all of the remaining Russian gas supplies to Europe. Russia has the capability of severing undersea gas pipelines from Norway to the UK and Europe, whilst denying that he has already carried out such action. 
The Eastern European War will in all probability be a very long and drawn out conflict lasting years if not decades. 
We must be prepared for such an eventuality.

attributes.background: The Chancellor of the Exchequer has said that he wants energy consumption to be reduced by 15% by 2030, and that consumers could save up to £500 by reducing their energy usage by 15%. We want the Government and Parliament to lead by example and reduce their own energy usage by 15%.
attributes.additional_details: In light of the Government's ambitions for reducing energy usage, and comments by the Chancellor of the Exchequer on domestic energy use, I would like to see the Government and Parliament reduce the energy consumption for which they are responsible by 15%, benchmarked against previous usage.

attributes.background: The Government need to alter the eligibility criteria for Prime Ministers to receive the Public Duty Costs Allowance (PDCA) of £115000 once they have resigned from the position of Prime Minister. The criteria needs to be changed so that you have to have served a full term in order to qualify.
attributes.additional_details: In light of the high turnover of UK Prime Ministers, and the current economic situation, it is not ethical for each Prime Minister to qualify for the PDCA. In her 45 days as PM Liz Truss earnt £25k in salary & severance. She will also earn £115k a year from the PDCA. In a situation where people are unable to afford energy bills, the PDCA is an unacceptable use of public money. The public should not fund Prime Minister’s and political party’s inability to organise themselves and do their jobs.

attributes.background: Make it illegal to charge standing changes on utility bills so customers only pay for the energy (or utility) they use. This is the case for water, oil and petrol, so there is no reason it cannot work for gas and electric.
attributes.additional_details: To reduce energy bills for low energy users and provide a fairer pricing structure that encourages people to conserve energy and helps them through the energy crisis.

attributes.action: Provide adequate support for our High street during the energy crisis.
attributes.background:
Change government policy to reflect the following; 
 
1) Reduction in VAT to 5% until the energy crisis is under control.
2) Introduce business rate rebates.
3) Re-Introduce a cap on energy price rises.  
4) Proactive launch of new decarbonisation and grant schemes to support SME’s
attributes.additional_details:
Since February 2021, small businesses have seen their gas & energy costs rise over 400% with further increases anticipated resulting in record levels of business failure. 

Our high street has survived unprecedented challenges arising from the pandemic, & despite having not fully recovered we once again face an existential threat which has already resulted in many thousands of businesses to cease trading, with inevitable mass business failure if adequate and immediate action isn’t taken.

rejection.details:
We can only accept petitions about things the Government or Parliament are directly responsible for.

Decisions about local clean air zones are a matter for the relevant local authority, not the UK Government or Parliament.

You could raise your issue with a local councillor who represents you. You can find out who your local councillors are, and how to contact them, by entering your post code here: https://www.gov.uk/find-your-local-councillors

attributes.action: Remove the merit order for Energy pricing. 100% Renewables = Renewables pricing
attributes.background:
Removing the Merit order of power will ensure energy users that have invested in renewable power over years of paying more for said renewables will get the benefits of those renewables entering the grid.
People that didn't have the forsight to opt in for renewables will pay for their past choices.
attributes.additional_details:
As discussed by Good Energy on the blog linked below, the current Wholesale Energy Price is determined by the Merit Order of energy.
That means that regardless of selecting 100% renewable energy or not, you are paying for the expensive gas kWs of power entering the grid.
Removing the merit order will ensure those that have invested in Renewables being added to the grid will get that benefit now.
https://www.goodenergy.co.uk/why-does-the-price-of-gas-drive-electricity-prices-including-renewables/

rejection.details:
Petitions must ask for a clear action from the Government or Parliament. We can see that you'd like to reform how energy prices are set to create more of a link between the price you pay for energy and whether you've "opted in" to renewables. 

Unfortunately, it isn't clear how removing the merit order for pricing would achieve this. While there are renewable energy tariffs, most energy tariffs do not specify the technologies that will be used, and indeed use a mix of different technologies. It's unclear how removing the merit order would guarantee that the tariff would be based on a renewable technology source.

You might be able to start a petition calling for the Government to reform how it sets the prices which energy generators receive from customers. The Government is currently consulting on this area - you might like to feed into its consultation. Its consultation closes on 10 October: https://www.gov.uk/government/consultations/review-of-electricity-market-arrangements

attributes.action: Prevent MPs from claiming energy costs until the energy crisis is over.
attributes.background: Take significant action to manage the impact of energy price rises on ordinary people and particularly trouser who are economically and physically vulnerable such as the poor, the elderly and children.
attributes.additional_details: Government has an obligation to protect the population of the UK. Failing to manage the energy crisis, as they currently are, will put millions at risk of poverty or death.

rejection.details:
We can't accept your petition because the UK Government and Parliament aren't responsible for the issue you raise. The Independent Parliamentary Standards Authority (IPSA) is responsible for deciding on MPs' expenses and pay. IPSA is independent of both Parliament and Government.

You can find out how to contact IPSA here:

http://www.theipsa.org.uk/about-us/contact-us/

attributes.action: Introduce right to 'Net Metering' for generation of renewable energy
attributes.background: Net Metering would credit the amount of energy exported during times of surplus against import at times when generation is low or not available.
attributes.additional_details:
Any account holder with grid-connected on-site renewable generation should have access to this type of contract.

The Feed in Tariff for renewable energy generation on homes and businesses closed to new entrants. Since then, payment for generation & export has not kept pace with rapidly rising cost of energy purchase.

Smart meters measure electricity import from, and export to the grid. This makes it technically possible to implement a Net Metering contract.

Example: Solar system credit would be accrued during clear sunny days and paid back later.

An account holder with surplus energy credit could donate to others, to people in need.

attributes.action: Impose an profit cap for energy companies per kWh
attributes.background: There should be a flat cap on the amount of profit that can be made per kWh instead of a percentage.  This will bring users bill costs down and prevent profiting from the energy crisis
attributes.additional_details: Currently energy companies make a percentile markup profit on energy bills.  This means that as wholesale prices increase, their profits increase, whilst the public have to pay more money.

rejection.details: We can't accept your petition because the UK Government and Parliament aren't responsible for the issue you raise. Decisions on the energy price cap levels are a matter for Ofgem rather than the UK Government or Parliament directly.

attributes.action: Order Ofgem to not increase (and ideally reduce) the energy price cap in October
attributes.background: This petition is requesting that Ofgem reduces the price cap in October, and directs energy companies to not have differential tariffs for non-direct debit paying customers. Government should support those energy companies in difficulty and reduce the standing charge impact to consumers.
attributes.additional_details: Ofgem have the power to control the domestic and commercial energy market, and the impact this has on the lives of millions. Energy underpins goods production, health, wealth and a key driver of inflation. If Ofgem reduced the price cap and standing charges, and instead the Goverment used the additional VAT and unexpected windfalls to support industry shortfalls, this would have a material impact. This is a much simpler and likely cheaper mechanism than providing funds direct to the public.

attributes.action: Cap Fuel costs to 4% annually
attributes.background: The energy companies profit hugely whilst we struggle to meet fuel costs. Please cap inflation to help out. At this time the shareholders need to accept smaller gains. The French government has capped the price rises to 4% during this crisis. Maybe we could cap to 6%.
attributes.additional_details: We need to act to prevent deaths from hypothermia and possibly hyperthermia. Furthermore people want to overload the grid to cut out circuits. Again this could lead to deaths as some people have life saving equipment at home plus no fuel means no heat or cooking leading to  illness and deaths from hypothermia during winter. Others may resort to more dangerous methods of cutting fuel costs. If they don't know what they're doing this would endanger their neighbours & community.

rejection.details: We can't accept your petition because the UK Government and Parliament aren't responsible for the issue you raise. The cost of energy is a matter for energy companies, while the energy price cap is a decision for Ofgem.

attributes.action: Force the energy companies to pay the cost of living payments
attributes.background: The huge rise in energy costs has been caused by a lack of planning and corporate greed by the big energy providers. Their record profits should pay for the problem they caused.
attributes.additional_details: Energy companies have been making record profits while charging customers more. They use the excuse of the war in Ukraine and this is coupled with very poor planning for the exit of the pandemic restrictions. It is completely immoral for the cost of living payments to be covered by general taxation. These companies profits will not cover the tax burden as they will move money around to avoid tax. They should be forced to pay for a problem they caused and exploited for profits.

rejection.details:
We understand you're concerned about cost of living support, and want energy companies to pay towards these. However it's not clear how what you're proposing is different from the Energy Profits Levy the Government announced in May. You can read more about this Levy here: https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/cost-of-living-support/energy-profits-levy-factsheet-26-may-2022.

You could have a petition calling for a levy on energy companies to pay for cost of living support, so long as it was clear how this levy was different to the one already announced.

You may like to sign this petition which calls for a related action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/607983

attributes.action: Control the ability of Energy Suppliers to raise direct debits freely
attributes.background: Energy suppliers do not use the amount of energy you use to determine a fair direct debit, they increased my direct debit from £55 a month to £143 within a month, even though they owe me money. They should not be allowed to do this, I don't know how, OFGEM or whoever should restrict this via banks
attributes.additional_details: Cap how much an energy supplier, or anyone for that matter, can increase a direct debit without approval via customer and the regulator. Then they will probably insist on higher direct debits from the start, my supplier wanted £150 from the start so this increase is no surprise. Customers should pay for what they use, not excess with the justification that customers may get behind with their bills. Some customers may not know what they use, some not afford to pay far more than they use

rejection.details:
Ofgem is already investigating this issue. You can find out more here

https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-61309576

If you'd like something different, such as a new rule applying to all direct debits, you could start a new petition clearly setting that out.

attributes.action: Put a legislation in to stop energy company’s charging excess standing charges
attributes.background: Government has pushed for Smart meters to be put into homes and business which should have helped understand the energy we are using however energy companies now have reduced the amount of times they read there meters but they have continued to increase standing charges on meters from 10p per meter
attributes.additional_details:
Around 5 years ago to now an average of 50p per meter! This has seen everyone’s energy bills increase from the energy companies doing less! 
I propose that everyone in the U.K. who has a smart meter can only be charged 5p per meter per day standing charge and this will help with the cost of living and also increase more people getting smart meters! There should be a law passed to stop energy companies from charging whatever they like and set one price

rejection.details:
We can only accept petitions about things the Government or Parliament are directly responsible for.

Decisions about standing charges are a matter for utility providers and Ofgem, not the UK Government or Parliament.

The price cap is a cap on a unit of gas and electricity, with standing charges taken into account. Find out more about the energy price cap, including how it includes standing charges, here: https://www.ofgem.gov.uk/check-if-energy-price-cap-affects-you

attributes.action: Immediately implement a fuel price cap on petrol and diesel fuel suppliers.
attributes.background: Implement a cap on the price that suppliers can charge for petrol and diesel fuel, similar to the cap on energy suppliers. A cap is essential to ensure families can afford to live. The cut in fuel duty tax hasn't stopped suppliers hiking prices, punishing the working class simply for owning a car.
attributes.additional_details: Most households rely on a petrol/diesel powered car for day to day life; some simply cannot do their job without a car. Very few can afford to switch to an electric/hybrid car. A fuel price cap would aid many families already struggling with increased costs of living. While the government have reduced fuel duty, it has not stopped petrol companies from hiking prices to compensate, with Shell making record profits. People will soon have to choose between eating or travelling to work.

rejection.details:
We can only accept petitions about things the Government or Parliament are directly responsible for. The Government isn't responsible for setting the price of fuel and energy, which is a matter for suppliers.

We have published the following petition, which you might like to sign:

Set up an independent regulator to monitor and regulate vehicle fuel pricing: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/605282
